conclusion: Analyze relative motion to determine collision time.
Collision occurs if Car A's displacement relative to Car B equals or exceeds initial distance.
Collision occurs when positions are the same, assuming Car A catches up.
Initial distance between cars is d = x_B0 - x_A0.
Collision occurs when difference in displacements equals initial distance d.
Car A initial velocity is 25 m/s, stops at 25 s.
Car A acceleration is -1 m/s^2.
Car A velocity function is v_A(t) = 25 - t.
Car B initial velocity is 15 m/s, stops at 30 s.
Car B acceleration is -0.5 m/s^2.
Car B velocity function is v_B(t) = 15 - 0.5t.
Displacement of Car A is Δx_A(t) = 25t - 0.5t^2.
Displacement of Car B is Δx_B(t) = 15t - 0.25t^2.
Collision occurs when Δx_A(t_c) - Δx_B(t_c) = d.
Initial distance d is difference in total stopping distances.
At t=20s, both cars have the same velocity.
Displacement of Car A at t=20s is 300 m.
Displacement of Car B at t=20s is 200 m.
Difference in displacement at t=20s is 100 m.
Collision occurs if initial distance d is less than or equal to 100 m.
If d < 100 m, collision occurs before t=20s.
If d = 50 m, collision occurs at t ≈ 5.86 s.
Collision is inevitable given braking profiles.
Maximum closing distance occurs at t=20s.
